comments.commentBody: Sorry, no love from me on this one.  You really had to have an imagination to see two sets of two blocks each as an apostrophe and a comma, and while identical, different because of where they are on the grid.  And "two dashes"?  That's a common phrase?  And the diagonal group of blocks?  I wondered if "staircase" was a typographical term.  Just a long slog with a dead-on-arrival interest level.

I thought this one was great fun, although it took me longer than it should have to start thinking typographically. My only real problem was hanging onto AMOROUS when it was AMATORY. I loved SEE STARS.

ART ROOM was a little funky, but I was OK with PEN CASES once I couldn't get PENCIL CUPS to fit in 8 squares.

Split pea soup always reminds me of the story in one of the George and Martha books when he pours it into his loafers on the sly to avoid eating the stuff but does not want to offend her.

Good puzzle. Got it all except for the KEPI-KEN cross.
What this post lacks....
If it makes us safer, I'm all for it. For those of you whining about it, do us all a favor and take a bus.
I don't mind the enhanced pat down, as long as a female employee does it.
This would be great for the rail industry, if only it could get it together to build a high speed rail system.

As a spectroscopist, I just wanted to point out that both the x-rays and millimeter-wavelength systems are using electromagnetic radiation, i.e. photons. The x-ray photons pass through the body, while the millimeter-wavelength photons bounce off of it.

#45, Philip: Our hats are off to you for taking a stand against the TSA!

Find an excellent lawyer and go for it all!

Thank you, sir. You and your girlfriend are true patriots!

The use of these machines has become gospel to managers in the TSA because the attempted attack on Christmas day in Detroit badly scared them; a successful attack on an airliner in the USA would cause many to question the premise of the whole organization.  This faith is being maintained despite questions about the actual effectiveness of the machines & it's operators.  The new administrator of the TSA, John Pistole, really needs to dig deep into the organization of the agency & start ruthlessly eliminating things which aren't working or are wasteful.  Unfortunately, it appears as of now that he is being subsumed by his own charge, as happens so often in Washington D.C.

Low-level radiation isn't innocuous. I read at least one study (in the NYT, I think, some years ago) that dental x-rays in moms were linked to low birth-weight babies.

It's no surprise the government is doing this; It's the same system that allows corporations to put anything and everything into our air, water, and soil. Our only recourse? Sue. And that's for the fortunate few who can afford it. Until enough of us stand up and say no, it's just going to continue.

$600 million fine.  How much do they have to overcharge in order to cover this expense?  Who pays for it?  Everybody that has any type of health insurance.  I am all for help for migraine sufferers, but why do we let these corporations gouge us so badly?

Am I the only one here who sees something really minimal here: "Chronic migraine patients treated with Botox reported 120 fewer hours of headache a month, he said. By comparison, people treated with placebo injections reported 80 fewer headache hours a month, he said."

And, what's the litany of long-term effects of being injected with Botox besides the pharmaceutical company making billions of dollars from the health care industry...

Last year I had $33,000 in a money market acct with Fidelity and the interest on it was about $3 a month.

I also had a Fidelity credit card with a $3,000 balance and the interest charge on that was a little over $30 a month.

So Fidelity pays me $3 a month for the use of my money, and then lends it out for $330, if my HS math is correct. Quite the mark-up there, if you ask me

I am one the seniors who is a victim of this massive transfer from the prudent to the irresponsible and corrupt. Why is that the Republicans who scream their lungs out about the unfair income transfer when the government taxes the rich for programs that aid the needy are so silent about this? Is it because their rich constituency is the beneficiary?

I never believed that our financial system would collapse without the Paulsen bail-out. I do not believe that this transfer benefits the people of this country. I am disgusted that both political parties serve the same corporate clients who buy them off.

Let's see the U.S. is in hock up to it's eyeballs due to TARP, Stimulus 1, Auto Bailouts, what have you, and 'savers' have earned essentially zip for nearly two years as a means to bail out banks, and they thought the housing market. And rather than this being borne by the casino consumers that borrowed against homes, got in over their heads, the frugal people get reamed. Wonder why there is so little confidence in politicians and why a mindset begins to set in of every person for themselves when it is perceived a tilted playing board is now the norm?

This is why we need to wrest control of interest rates away from the Fed. The Fed's main constituency is its member banks, who are the same firms that drove this debt crisis in the first place.

Isn't it a great irony that a debt crisis that spawned a major financial meltdown and recession is being "solved" by even cheaper credit and even more borrowing? If the goal is to reinflate the bubble for a short time, so that we can then pop the bubble again, this strategy makes zany sense. If the goal is long-term economic stability, however, we ought to be trying to reward savers and discourage debtors. The solution to too much debt is not more debt!

This is terrible my parents are about to retire and they saved their whole lives.  Literally ever single cent they have ever saved is sweat and blood money. They have recently asked me is it a good time to go into the stock market.   Of course I berated them for even entertaining the thought.  Bernanke please if you read this, you are driving desperate soon to be retirees who should not take any risk into the stock market.  Have you no conscience?

Its going to get a lot worse for savers when the Fed (and Obama) succeed in engineering major inflation through deficit spending and printing money. Inflation helps borrowers and decimates savers.

In addition these low rates will cause people to move into riskier investments in search of higher yields. This is what drove investors in to CDOs built using sub-prime mortgages in the first place.

Its also going to lead to another bubble, the million dollar question is where?

"Two Robust Speeches".  So, you think that makes up for the negligence and incompetence of the past two years?  I do not agree.  And, believe me when I say that my disagreement is laced with frustration and anger.  That makes me typical of the majority of voters in this country, right now.  The Democrats have had huge majorities in both houses of Congress as well as the Presidency.  Obama has no excuse, and no-one to blame but himself and his fellow Democrats in the majority in Congress.  "We the People" are going to be making big changes in November, and Obama, as well as the new Congress, had better be paying attention.
Very nice puzzle, I thought. Not a quibble. Great example of using every square in the grid. I liked the novel theme, the open corners, the scrabbly fill. Congrats on the debut, Kevin.
Terrible Nano, you have to look at it to switch? I blind switch my 2-year old model all the time - excercising, in the car etc. Fergit it. Bring it back the way it was (FM radio -- good)

Personally, I find the new old Shuffle a humorous retro-development. For those who still like screens and buttons, consider the SanDisk Sansa Clip+: a real (albeit small, text-only) screen, real control buttons, and a micro-SD slot to take a $60 8GB player up to 24GB for less than $100; as well as great sound (which some people actually think is important).

Not that the new iPod Nano doesn't look intriguing in a fun sorta way, although I don't know if it has legs beyond that. And an iPod Touch still is in my future, once the capacity doubles (next year?) and it becomes a jukebox of a player (sorry, I'm not Apple's ideal customer: I don't buy a new player every year--call me a displaced frugal New Englander ...).
I really like the new nano, it's perfect if you like touch screen for selections but generally prefer audio to video during working hours.    A home run in my book!
Glad to see those incredibly stupid earbud controls are gone...now I can safely buy another couple of Shuffles to tide me over past the next egregious rejiggering...
